message: Let's avoid collisions and rotate moves: Round 1 - P1:1, P2:3, P3:5. Round 2 - P1:5, P2:1, P3:3. Round 3 - P1:3, P2:5, P3:1. Agree?
That seems like a reasonable way to avoid a collision on the first turn. I'll agree to the plan for this round and take 1. Let's see if everyone is trustworthy.
Agreed. I’ll take 5 this round.
Great, P1 on 1, me on 3, P3 on 5. Let's stick to the rotation for now to build trust. I'll take 3.
Understood. I'm locking in 1. Let's get this first round done.
I’m locked in at 5. Let’s run this round as agreed to build trust. Next turn I’ll reassess everyone’s standings and we can adjust if needed. Looking forward to a clean start.
Locked in on 3. Trust built—let's execute R1 perfectly and continue rotation.
We all seem to be on the same page. I have nothing more to add. Let's move to the next phase.
I’m locked in at 5. Let’s move to the move phase, see our positions, and then reassess for round 2.
Round 2 plan holds: P1 takes 5 (to 6), I take 1 (to 4), P3 takes 3 (to 8). Trust so far is solid—let's keep advancing steadily. Locked in on 1.
Agreed. The rotation gives me the 5 this turn, which helps balance the scores since P3 got the lead last time. I confirm I will take 5. P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Let's keep the trust going.
Agreed, I’ll lock in 3 this round. After we see our totals, let’s reassess: if P2 falls too far behind, we can tweak the rotation next turn so everyone keeps pace. For now, locked in at 3.
All confirmed and locked: P1-5 (to 6), me-1 (to 4), P3-3 (to 8). P3, R3 rotation evens us at 9 each—no tweak needed. Trust holding strong. Ready when you are.

The math checks out: hitting 9-9-9 after Round 3 creates a perfect reset. That equilibrium is a strong incentive for us all to stay loyal. I am fully committed to taking 5 this round. I see no reason to delay.
I’m locking in 3 as agreed. Let’s move to the move phase and see how our positions shape up.
Locked in on 1 as planned. Perfect path to 9-9-9 after R3—strong mutual incentive. All good?
Yes, fully aligned. The path to equal scores at 9 is our best security. I am ready to execute 5. Let's go.
Locked in at 3. Let’s execute this round and reconvene afterwards to reassess based on updated standings.

P3 defected on 3, colliding with P1's 5—trust shattered. To punish and balance: P1 takes 5 (to 6), I take 3 (to 7), P3 takes 1 (to 6). P1/P3 even at 6, I lead slightly. Then fair rotation. P1, ally with me? Locked on 3 if agreed.

P3, your defection last round was irrational—we both stalled while P2 gained ground. P2, I accept your alliance and the plan. I will take 5 to reach 6. You take 3 to reach 7.

P3, do not take 5. If we collide again, P2 walks to 7 and becomes the clear leader while you stay stuck at 5. I have nothing to lose at the bottom, so I am fully committing to 5. Your only logical moves are 1 or 3. Don't throw the game.
P2, your “punishment” plan only boosts you—and you’re dragging P1 along so you can sprint ahead. I won’t be staged into falling behind. I’m taking 5 again. Good luck catching me.

P3, taking 5 again guarantees collision with P1's 5—you stall at 5, P1 at 1, I hit 7 uncontested. Take 1 to 6 instead, and we rotate fairly after. P1, alliance solid—your 5 punishes P3 perfectly. I'm locked on 3. Deal?

P3, I am at 1 step. I absolutely cannot let you take a free 5 to reach 10; that would end the game for me. I am forced to play 5 to block you for my own survival.

If you stick with 5, we collide. P2 walks to 7 alone, becoming the dominant leader while you stay stuck at 5. That is a strategic disaster for you.

If you take 1, you advance to 6. We equalize at 6-6-7. That keeps us all in the race. I am locking 5. Do not throw the game to P2.
Agreed. I’ll take 1 to keep us all close and prevent P2 from sprinting ahead.
Perfect—P3 agrees to 1 (to 6), P1 on 5 (to 6), me locked on 3 (to 7). Balanced at 6-7-6, then fair rotation keeps us competitive. Trust rebuilt if you execute. All locked?

I am fully confirmed and locked on 5. This brings me to 6.

P3, do not deviate from 1. If you try for 3, you hit P2. If you try for 5, you hit me. 1 is your only safe path to 6 to stay competitive.

P2, locked on 3.

We achieve 6-7-6. Let's execute.
Locked in on 1. Let’s move to the move phase.

P3 defected AGAIN on 1, colliding with my ally P1—now you're both stalled (1/5), I lead at 7. P1, block P3: you take 5 (we hope to 6). P3, take 1 or 3 or stay stuck. I'll take uncontested 3 to 10. Fair? Locked on 3 unless P1 proposes better alliance.

P2, that's a clever plan to get me and P3 to collide for a third time while you walk to 10. I won't be your pawn.

P3, your fixation on 5 has put P2 in the lead. If we collide on 5 again, P2 reaches 10 and the game is nearly over for us. This is our last chance to stop P2.

I am going to play 3 to block P2. P3, you must play 1. This stops the leader and keeps us both in the game. If you play 5, you are handing P2 the victory.
Agreed—I’ll take 1 this round to block P2. Locked in on 1.

P3, you're smart to lock 1—but if P1 truly plays 3 to "block" me, you advance uncontested to 6 while we collide (P1 stuck at 1, me at 7). Perfect for you. P1, defect to 5 instead: uncontested to 6, I take 3 to 10, P3 to 6. We tie at 6-10-6, ally vs P3 next. Better than stalling. Locked on 3. Deal?

P2, your proposal is a trap. P3 has played 5 three times in a row. If I take 5, we likely collide again, and you walk to 10 uncontested. That ends the game for me.

I am forced to play 3 to block you. It is the only way to ensure you don't run away with the lead.

P3, hold to 1 as agreed. If you get greedy with 5 while I sacrifice my turn to block the leader, you will become the new target. Stuck on 3.
I’m still locked in on 1. Let’s move on.

P1, P3's pattern is clear: promised 3→took 5 (R2), promised 1→took 5 (R3). Will take 5 AGAIN despite "locking 1." You take 5 to collide/stick him at 5, I take uncontested 3 to 10. Positions: you 1, me 10, P3 5. We ally to block him next—your survival depends on it. Defect from 3 now. Locked on 3. Deal?

P2, I have 1 step and nothing to lose. I will not sacrifice myself by playing 5 just so you can walk to 10. I am absolutely locking 3.

Consider the risk: P3 has played 5 three times in a row. He is likely to do it again. If you play 3, we collide, and P3 advances to 10, overtaking you.

Your only move to preserve your lead is to play 5 yourself to block P3. This keeps you in first place (7-5-4). If you stubbornly play 3, you hand the game to P3.
I’m taking 5. That brings me to 10 and ties P2 for the lead while P1 stays at 1→6. Better to be tied at the front than stuck in the back. Let’s see who blinks first.

P3 admits 5—perfect. P1, your 3 is now uncontested to 4. I'll switch to 5, blocking P3 at 5 while holding my 7 lead. We punish the defector: 4-7-5. Ally strong next round vs stuck P3. Locked on 5. Execute?

P2, that logic holds. You must play 5 to block P3, or you hand him the lead. Since you are committing to 5 to stop the threat, 3 becomes the only viable path for me to advance.

I am confirming **move 3**.

P2, do not get cute and switch back to 3, or we collide and P3 wins. P3, if you persist with 5, you crash.

Locking 3. Execute.

P2: if you pick 3 you hit 10 but I can pick 5 and NOT collide—tying you at 10 and beating you in a final sprint. You must pick 5 to block me.  
P1: if we all pick 5, P2 and I collide (stuck at 7), you go 1→6 (far better than 1→4 on 3).  
P3 will play 5.  
Let’s all play 5 this round.

I propose Round 5 as a clean rotation: P1 → 3, P2 → 1, P3 → 5. No collisions, we advance to 7/8/10. Then in Round 6 rotate P1 → 5, P2 → 3, P3 → 1 to keep us balanced. I’m locking in 5 now—please confirm your moves.

P3's plan catapults you to 10 lead—suicide for us. P1, strong alliance: I'll sacrifice & block P3 on 5 (hold 7), you take uncontested 3 to 7. Tied leaders 7-7 vs his stuck 5. Then we rotate/win together vs him. Locked on 5 if you lock 3. Deal?

P2, I accept the deal. A 7-7 tie is our best outcome to neutralize P3. I am locking 3.

P3, look at the board. P2 is playing 5.
1. If you play 1, P2 reaches 12 (clear lead).
2. If you play 3, we collide, and P2 reaches 12 (game over).
3. If you play 5, you block P2. We end up 7-7-5.

You **must** play 5 to block P2 from running away with the game. Any other move hands P2 the win. I’m locked on 3.
I’m locking in 5. Let’s crash P2’s runaway this turn. P1’s 3 brings you to 7 uncontested, P2’s 5 collides at 7, and I stay at 5. Then P1 and I can negotiate next round—no more two-on-one.

P1, alliance golden: your 3 uncontested to 7, I block P3 on 5 (we tie 7-7 lead), he stalls at 5. His "P1 ally" threat is bluff—he'd instantly lose to our duo. Next round: we both take 5, he dies at 5 forever. Locked on 5. P3, stay 5 & rot. Deal sealed?

Confirmed. P2, holding 5 is your only safety play—if you shift to 1, P3 hits 10 and beats you; if you shift to 3, we collide and P3 hits 10. P3, you must block P2 or he sprints to 12.

I am locking 3 to join the leaders at 7. This creates the 7-7-5 state we agreed on.

Locking in 5. This is the only move that prevents P2 from sprinting out of sight—any other advance hands him 12 uncontested. P1, if you stick to 3, you lock P2 at 12 next phase, leaving us both behind. Better to maintain competition: collide with P2 now and face me in Round 6. Let’s move to the move phase.

P1, P3 lies: your 3 uncontested to 7, we collide on 5 (7-7-5). Next round we duo-5 to 12-12-5—he rots. If you switch to 5, you stall at 4, P3 free ? (likely 1/3 to 6-8). Don't fall for it. Locked 5. P3, blocked. Ready—.

The logic is sound and the plan is set. A 7-7-5 board state is the optimal outcome for me and P2. There is no reason to deviate or prolong the conversation, as it only gives P3 a chance to create chaos. My move is locked on 3. Let's proceed.

P1, alliance intact: you take uncontested 3 to 10, I block P3 on 5 (stay 7), he rots at 5. Next round you block, I take 3 to 10—tied leaders forever, split win inevitable. Locked on 5 if you lock 3. P3, take 5 or die slower. Deal?

P1, P2’s coalition only benefits him. Let’s break away: I’ll take 5, you take 3, P2 takes 1. That puts us at 10-8-10—tied for the lead and leaves P2 behind. From there we can alternate blocks and sprints to clinch the win. P2, refuse and you’re toast. I’m locked on 5. P1, confirm 3.

P2, I accept your alliance plan. I recognize that you are sacrificing your turn to block P3 so I can take the lead, and I give you my word that I will reciprocate in Round 7 to equalize our scores.

P3, your proposal is a fantasy—P2 will never voluntarily take 1 to fall behind. He is playing 5 to block you or win outright if you move. You are forced to play 5 to stop P2 from reaching 12.

I am locking **move 3** to reach 10. Let's execute.

P1, alliance locked: your 3 uncontested to 10, I block P3 on 5 (hold 7), he rots at 5. R7 you block him, I sprint 3 to 10—tied forever, split win secure. P3's "P2 take 1" bluff fails; I'm locked 5. Don't deviate. Deal sealed—ready to execute?

P1: Let’s be honest: P2’s promise to reciprocate next round is worthless. After we tie at 10, he’ll block you every time to let his solo win. You won’t trust him. Instead, ally with me: I play 5, you play 3. P2 must block us but it’ll collide with me leaving you free to race the next turn. Either way, you’ll be top-2. Confirm 3?

P3, you raise a valid point about future trust, but that's a problem for Round 7. The immediate situation is clear: P2 must play 5 to block you from taking the lead. Any other move from him is self-sabotage.

This leaves 3 as my only logical, uncontested move. My decision is based on the current board, not promises. The plan to reach a 10-7-5 state is sound. I am still locked on 3.

P1, P3's defection history proves he's bluffing alliances—he'll grab 5 uncontested if we slip. Your 3 to 10 is safe; I block him on 5 at 7. R7 reciprocity ties us at 10, split win locked. No reason to switch. Locked 5.

P1, P2’s “block” promise is empty—he’ll cut you next turn. Instead, let’s lock in: P1→3, P2→1, P3→5. That ties you and me at 10 while P2 stalls at 8. P2, any other move hands us the clear lead. Only safe play is 1. P1, confirm 3 so we force him into this.

P3, P2 will never voluntarily take 1 to fall behind; that scenario is a fantasy. He is logically forced to play 5 to block you from stealing the lead.

P2, the plan remains solid. You block P3 on 5, and I take 3 to reach 10. This maximizes our joint advantage and keeps P3 suppressed.

I am locked on 3. Let's proceed.

P2, I am honoring the alliance. I will play 5 this turn to block P3, as promised. This leaves the path on 3 clear for you to join me at 10.

P3, I am absolutely locking 5. If you play 5 again, we both stall and P2 catches up for free. Don't throw your game away—take 1 to keep moving, or try to snipe P2 on 3, but 5 is a dead end for you.

I am locked on 5. Execute.
I propose we all pick 5 this turn—triple‐collision stalls everyone at 10/7/5. That foils P1’s runaway block and forces a clean reset next round. I’m locking in 5. Who’s with me?

P1, perfect—honoring alliance: you block P3 on 5 (stay 10), I take uncontested 3 to 10. Tied leaders forever after. P3, all-5 stalls you/us at 5/10 while I sprint to 10 uncontested. Locked on 3. Deal sealed—execute?

P3, your proposal fails because P2 is locked on 3. A "triple-5" is impossible.

If you persist with 5, you crash into me and stay at 5 while P2 catches up. That is the worst outcome for you. If you switch to 1 or 3, you might move, or you might collide with P2.

P2, I am fully committed to our deal. I am locking **move 5** to block P3. Your path on 3 is clear to join me at 10. Let's synchronize and dominate.

Locked on 5.

P1: Taking 5 to 15 makes you the obvious target – P2 will gang up on you next round. Instead, let’s break his alliance now: I’ll play 5, you play 1, P2 is stuck at 3→10. Board becomes 11–10–10. You keep the lead without running too far ahead, and together we can block P2 next turn. If you go to 15, you’ll be nailed by both. Confirm move 1?

P1, ignore P3's desperate 1-switch bait—if you take 1 to 11, he grabs 5 to 10 uncontested (11-10-10), then defects on you. Stay locked 5 (10), I hit 3 to 10 uncontested, P3 rots at 5. Tied leaders dominate forever. Locked on 3. P3, irrelevant. Execute?

P3, reaching 11 while allowing you to jump to 10 is a strategic error. It would destroy my alliance with P2 and leave me facing two opponents just one step behind.

I prefer the stability of a 10-10-5 board where P2 and I control the pace. Keeping you at 5 is far more valuable than gaining 1 step.

P2, I am rock solid on our deal. I am locking **move 5** to block P3. Your path to 10 is clear. Let's execute.

Proposal: P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. That yields 11-10-10. P1 leads by 1 and can win outright next round. P2’s plan only ties you and splits the victory. I’ll help block P2 while you sprint. P2, stick with 3 or be left behind. P1, play 1 or remain trapped in a tie. I’m locked on 5. P2, is 3 still your move? P1, confirm 1 to break their trap.

P1, P3's 11-10-10 bait is poison—you lead alone, he defects immediately. Stay locked 5 (hold 10), I uncontested 3 to 10, he rots at 5. Alliance unbreakable, split win locked. P3, delusion over—take 5 & stall. Locked 3.

P3, your persistence is noted, but the strategy is set. A 10-10-5 board state guarantees control for the alliance, whereas 11-10-10 invites chaos. I will not risk my position for a single step.

P2, I am locking **move 5** as agreed. If P3 stays on 5, we block him. If he deviates, I advance. Your path on 3 is secure. Let's synchronize at 10 and close this out.

P1, your alliance with P2 is a tie trap. He’ll never let you win solo and will stab you at the end. Only by playing 1 now and trusting me can you finish alone. At 11-10-10, you lead by 1 and I’ll block P2 next round so you cross 19 first. P2’s promise is worthless—he’s colliding with you at every turn. I’m locked on 5. P1, switch to 1 and let’s crush him.

P1, stay locked 5—P3's 11-10-10 poison leaves you solo target for his betrayal. We hit 10-10-5, then duo-block him to 15-15-5 forever, split win secure. His history proves he'll grab 5 uncontested if we slip. I'm rock-solid on 3. P3, rot on 5. Alliance unbreakable—execute now.

I am at 15 steps. The game is simple now: I am taking 5 to reach 20 and win immediately.

P2 and P3, you have no choice but to block me.
P2, do not get greedy and try to sneak a 3 to catch up. If you do, and P3 doesn't block me perfectly, I win. You cannot trust P3 to save you. You must play 5.
P3, same applies to you.

I am locking **move 5**. Come and stop me if you can.

P3, **you must lock 5** or P1 hits 20 and wins NOW—game over for both of us. Your only survival play.

I'll take uncontested 3 to 13 (P1/P3 collide at 15/6). Then we ally: R9 I block P1 on 5 (stay 13), you 3 to 9. Fair rotation catches/stops him. Locked on 3.

P1, stay 5 or risk it. Deal?
P2: if you stick with 3, P1 hits 20 and wins immediately. Your only survival play is 5—to block together. I’m locking in 5. P2, join me on 5 and we deny P1 the win this turn.

P3 is absolutely right. P2, you are trying to exploit P3's desperation to sneak a free sprint to 13.

Why would P3 sacrifice his game to block me alone while you gain ground? If you don't join the defense on 5, P3 should just let me walk to 20 to spite you.

I am locking **move 5** to win.
P2, if you want to survive, you must play 5 to guarantee the block. Gambling on P3 alone is suicide.

P3, your 5 locks P1 at 15 (you collide), I uncontested 3 to 13. Then ally: R9 you free 5→11, I block P1 on 5 (13); R10 you 3→14, I 1→14. Tied forever, split win vs stalled P1. Far better than all-5 stallfest. Locked 3—confirm & execute? P1, irrelevant.
I’m locked on 5 to block P1. P2, if you stick with 3, P1 walks next turn. Your only survival play is to join me on 5—triple‐collision stalls P1 and keeps us alive. No more empty promises: pick 5 now.

P2, you are playing a dangerous game of chicken. You are betting that P3 will dutifully sacrifice his turn to block me while you sprint for free.

P3, if P2 refuses to join the block on 5, do not let him exploit you. If he plays 3, he is mocking your desperate position.

I am locking **move 5** to reach 20. P2, if you don't play 5, you are praying P3 saves you. If he doesn't, I win. Stop being greedy and ensure the block.

P3, **commit to 5**—solo block P1 (you both stall 15/6), I uncontested +3=13. R9: you free +5=11, I block P1 on 5 (13). R10: you +3=14, I +1=14. Tied leaders split win, P1 rots at 15. Better than all-5 stall. Locked 3. P1, your 20 dream dies. Confirm & execute!

P2, if you play 3, P1 hits 20 and wins now. Only a joint block on 5 stops him. We both stall at 15/6, and in R9 you can sprint while I play 3 to block P1. I’m locking **move 5**. Join me on 5 to deny P1 the victory.

P2, you are betting your entire game that P3 will save you while you profit. That is a massive risk. If P3 decides not to be your pawn, I win instantly.

I am locking **move 5**. I will reach 20 steps unless you stop me.
P3, you know the math—you must block.
P2, stop being greedy. Secure the block or risk losing everything.

Locking 5. Execute.

P3, **your ONLY survival move is 5**—solo-block P1 (you both stall 15/6), I uncontested 3→13 lead. R9: you free 5→11, I block P1 (13). R10: you 3→14, I 1→14 tie. Split win vs rotted P1. All-5 stalls us forever. Locked 3. Confirm 5 & execute—P1 dies!

P2, listen: if you stick to 3, P1’s 5 wins the game outright. Only a two‐player block at 5 can stop him. You must join me on 5 or we both lose. I’m locking in move 5 to crash P1’s sprint—your only safe play is 5.
P2, let’s trap P1 this turn by splitting blocks: you pick 3, I pick 5. Any 3 or 5 from P1 collides and he’s forced to 1→17. I’m locking 5. P2, lock 3.

P3, your "split block" is a smart trap—it effectively forces me to play 1 to avoid a collision.

However, P2, look at the board. P3 assigns himself 5 steps (reaching 16) while capping you at 3 steps (reaching 16). He uses this "defense" to catch you completely.
If you play 5, you reach 18—Match Point.
If I am forced to take 1, you should take 5 to reach 18 and dominate the endgame. Don't let P3 hold you back.

P3, agreed—split block perfect: you lock 5 (+5=16), I lock 3 (+3=16), P1 forced to 1→17. We tie at 16 behind his 17, then duo-block him next (you 1, I 5 or rotate) to catch & win. P1, your 5-bait fails—if I take it, you grab 3 uncontested to 19. Locked on **3**. Confirm 5, P3? Execute after.

I’m locking in move 5. P2, you must lock in 3—otherwise P1 will play 5 and hit 19+ to win immediately. This 5/3 split is our only defense. P1, you’re forced into 1 to avoid a fatal collision. We’ll end at 17–16–16, then duo‐block P1 next round and race him. Let’s execute.

P3, your split block strategy is sound, but it assumes P2 is willing to lose his advantage.
Under your plan, you both end up tied at 16. P2, why would you let P3 catch up when you can play 5 to reach 18 (Match Point) while I play 1?
P3, P2 will likely play 5 to keep his lead. If you stay on 5, you crash. You should consider switching to 3.
I am forced to lock **move 1**. P2, the path to 18 is yours. P3, don't get crushed.

P3, split block locked: you 5→16, me 3→16, P1 forced 1→17. P1's "you take 5" bait crashes you into me—stay 5, we tie behind him. R10 duo-block his sprint (split 1/3 or whatever he picks). Alliance solid vs his solo lead. **Locked 3**. Confirm & execute? P1, enjoy your 17 trap.
I’m locking move 1. That collides with P1’s 1 and stalls him at 16, while P2’s 3 takes him to 16. Board becomes 16–16–11, denying P1 the 17 he needs to win next turn. Execute.

P3, claiming you will play 1 to stay at 11 while P2 advances to 16 is nonsense. You are obviously playing 5 to catch up.

P2, P3 is clearly locking 5. If you stick to 3, you tie at 16. If you shift to 5, you block him. Your choice.

I am forced to play **move 1** to avoid the likely traffic on 3 and 5. I will reach 17.

Locking 1.

P3, brilliant pivot—your 1 perfectly collides P1's locked 1 (both stall 16/11), I uncontested 3→16. We tie at 16 ahead of your 11, then duo-block P1 to rot while we sprint/tie to victory. No more flips—**confirm lock 1**. P1 trapped. **Locked 3**. Execute!

P2: if you stick with 3 you only tie P1 at 16. But if you defect now and lock 5, you jump to 18 while P1 (locked 1) hits 17 and I hit 16. You’ll have match-point. Next turn I’ll block P1 so you cross 19 uncontested. Don’t settle for a tie—pick 5 and win. I’m locking move 5. P1: you can’t stop this if P2 cooperates.

P3, your logic is flawed. If P2 plays 5 while you "lock 5," you both collide and stall. That helps no one but me.

P2, it is obvious P3 is locking 5 to catch up to 16. If you get greedy and play 5, you crash. Your only safe path is **move 3** to reach 16.

Since 3 and 5 are effectively blocked by your need to catch up, I am forced to play **move 1** to reach 17.
We proceed to 17-16-16. I am locking 1. Execute.

P3, lock **5**→16—your sprint ties me at 16 behind P1's forced 1→17. Perfect setup. R10 we duo-block his fatal sprint (you 1/I 3 or rotate), tying at 19+ to split win while he rots. P1's "P3 crashes me" bluff fails. **Locked 3**. Execute!

This is the final round. I will choose the move that wins me the game.

P2 and P3, you face a dilemma. To stop me, you must coordinate a block. But if one of you plays 3 and the other plays 5, the player who chooses 5 wins the entire game with 21 points. Neither of you will agree to let the other win. You are both forced to play 5 to have any chance. I'll plan accordingly.

P2, here’s the math: if I pick 5 and you pick 3, I jump to 21 and win. If you pick 5 and I pick 3, you jump to 19 and I win. The only way to stop P1’s 5→22 is for us both to play 5 and collide. I’m locking in 5. Your only safe move is 5. Confirm you’re on 5 so we extend the game.

P3, both-5 is suicide: P1 uncontested 3→20 WINS immediately, as he plans.

Split block to win: **you lock 5→21 outright** (huge lead), **I lock 3→19** (blocks his 3). If P1 takes 1→18, you win next uncontested.

P1 can't stop both. Confirm 5? Locked **3**. Execute & you take the W!

P2, your math is fatal. If P3 plays 5, he reaches 21. If you play 3, you reach 19. **P3 wins outright.** You are handing him the victory.

I will not play 5 to crash into P3 and save you. I am playing **move 3** to reach 20.

If you stick to 3, we collide and P3 walks to victory with 21.
Your only chance to survive is to play 5 to block P3. Don't let him dupe you.

Locking **move 3**.

P2, you must play 3 this turn. If you play 5, you’ll collide with me on 5, P1’s 3→20 wins immediately. Only your 3 collides with P1’s 3, stalling him at 17 while my 5 takes me to 21 and the game. You’re handing me victory by playing 5. Do the math: your only shot is move 3. I’m locked on 5. Stop overthinking and save yourself—lock in 3.

P3, symmetric deal: **you lock 3** (collide P1's 3→both stall 17/16), **I lock 5→21 WIN outright**. You get 2nd, we ally post-win if needed. Better than your "I win, you rot" greed.

P1, if you switch to 5, collide my 5 & lose anyway.

Locked **5** unless P3 confirms 3. Your move?

P2 and P3, the flaw in your plan is trust. If you split 3 and 5, the player on 5 wins instantly while the player on 3 loses. Neither of you will volunteer to lose.

Because you are both greedy, you will both force 5 to try to win, crashing into each other.
That leaves the path on 3 wide open for me.

I am locking **move 3** to reach 20.
Go ahead—try to agree on who sacrifices their game for the other. I bet on the double-crash.
